greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle of the numerators of coefficients c(n,k) = [x^k] P(n,x) of certain polynomials P(n,x) given below.
comment: Let the polynomials P be defined by P(0,x)=u(0), P(n,x)= u(n) + x*Sum_{i=0..n-1} u(i)*P(n-i-1,x) and coefficients u(i)=1/i!. These u are reminiscent of the Taylor expansion of exp(x). Then P(n,x) = Sum_{k=0..n} c(n,k)*x^k.
n!*P(n,x) are the row polynomials of A152818. - _Peter Bala_, Oct 09 2011
Conjecture: All roots of P(n,x) are real, hence negative. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 10 2012
link: Jean-François Alcover, Plot showing roots of P(20,x)
example: The triangle c(n,k) and polynomials start in row n = 0 as:
maple: P := proc(n,x) option remember ; if n =0 then u(0); else u(n)+x*add( u(i)*procname(n-1-i,x),i=0..n-1) ; expand(%) ; fi; end:
A152650 := proc(n,k) p := P(n,x) ; numer(coeftayl(p,x=0,k)) ; end:
mathematica: ClearAll[u, p]; u[n_] := 1/n!; p[0][x_] := u[0]; p[n_][x_] := p[n][x] = u[n] + x*Sum[u[i]*p[n-i-1][x] , {i, 0, n-1}] // Expand; row[n_] := CoefficientList[p[n][x], x]; Table[row[n], {n, 0, 10}] // Flatten // Numerator (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 02 2012 *)
results.author: _Paul Curtz_, Dec 10 2008
ext: Edited and extended by _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 24 2009
